desc: A wrapper around an io.Process class that adds some convenience methods.
name: process.ProcessWrapper

methods.desc: Constructs a ProcessWrapper object that delegates to the specified underlying object.
methods.example:
Implementation

ProcessWrapper(this._delegate)
    : _stdout = new StreamController<List<int>>(),
      _stderr = new StreamController<List<int>>(),
      _stdoutDone = new Completer<void>(),
      _stderrDone = new Completer<void>() {
  _monitorStdioStream(_delegate.stdout, _stdout, _stdoutDone);
  _monitorStdioStream(_delegate.stderr, _stderr, _stderrDone);
}
methods.name: ProcessWrapper

methods.desc:
Kills the process.

Where possible, sends the signal to the process. This includes Linux and OS X. The default signal is ProcessSignal.sigterm which will normally terminate the process.

On platforms without signal support, including Windows, the call just terminates the process in a platform specific way, and the signal parameter is ignored.

Returns true if the signal is successfully delivered to the process. Otherwise the signal could not be sent, usually meaning that the process is already dead.
methods.example:
Implementation

@override
bool kill([io.ProcessSignal signal = io.ProcessSignal.sigterm]) {
  return _delegate.kill(signal);
}
methods.name: kill

props.desc:
A Future that completes when the process has exited and its standard output and error streams have closed.

This exists as an alternative to exitCode, which does not guarantee that the stdio streams have closed (it is possible for the exit code to be available before stdout and stderr have closed).

The future returned here will complete with the exit code of the process.
props.example:
Implementation

Future<int> get done async {
  int result;
  await Future.wait<void>(<Future<void>>[
    _stdoutDone.future,
    _stderrDone.future,
    _delegate.exitCode.then((int value) {
      result = value;
    }),
  ]);
  assert(result != null);
  return result;
}
props.name: done

props.desc:
Returns a Future which completes with the exit code of the process when the process completes.

The handling of exit codes is platform specific.

On Linux and OS X a normal exit code will be a positive value in the range 0..255. If the process was terminated due to a signal the exit code will be a negative value in the range -255..-1, where the absolute value of the exit code is the signal number. For example, if a process crashes due to a segmentation violation the exit code will be -11, as the signal SIGSEGV has the number 11.

On Windows a process can report any 32-bit value as an exit code. When returning the exit code this exit code is turned into a signed value. Some special values are used to report termination due to some system event. E.g. if a process crashes due to an access violation the 32-bit exit code is 0xc0000005, which will be returned as the negative number -1073741819. To get the original 32-bit value use (0x100000000 + exitCode) & 0xffffffff.

There is no guarantee that stdout and stderr have finished reporting the buffered output of the process when the returned future completes. To be sure that all output is captured, wait for the done event on the streams.
props.name: exitCode

props.desc: Returns the process id of the process.
props.name: pid

props.desc: Returns the standard error stream of the process as a Stream.
props.name: stderr

props.desc: Returns the standard input stream of the process as an IOSink.
props.name: stdin

props.desc: Returns the standard output stream of the process as a Stream.
props.name: stdout
